author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Thursday Briefing: Israeli Troops Clashed with Hezbollah
description: Plus, what we learned from fashion month.
content: Israel and Hezbollah said their troops were fighting at close range in southern Lebanon, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu weighed a military response to Iran for firing ballistic missiles at Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Piccata With a Smart, Meatless Twist
description: That buttery, briny combination of lemon, butter and capers is awesome on cauliflower.
content: I’m back from my trip to Turkey and Kurdistan, where, you won’t be surprised to hear, I ate spectacularly well. I was treated to ripe figs and juicy melon; yogurt-swirled dips scooped up with homemade flatbread; singed grilled fish brushed with pomegranate molasses; meaty kebabs cut from every part of the cow and lamb; and so many honeyed, flaky pastries that I think I might have to go on a baklava break, at least for a day or two. Such abundance in all things — except for vegetables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Daniel Dae Kim as a Playwright Unmasked in ‘Yellow Face’
description: David Henry Hwang’s 2007 play, now in a fine Broadway revival, is a pointed critique of identity, masquerading as a mockumentary.
content: To write yourself into your own play is to put on a very curious mask. If it’s flattering, is it honest? If it’s honest, why bother?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Warmly Received in Asia, Pope Feels Chill in Belgium
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 2, 2024.
content: “He walked into the lions’ den.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kasia Pilat and Alexa Weibel
title: Whole Foods Tried to Change This Cake Recipe. Customers Lost It.
description: The grocery chain’s Berry Chantilly cake has a cult following and an extremely vocal fan base.
content: When Lisa Younes visited her local Whole Foods Market in Berkeley, Calif., last month she expected to walk out with a slice of her beloved Berry Chantilly cake: With its lofty layers of almond-scented cake and fluffy mascarpone frosting dotted with fresh mixed berries, it had become her go-to sweet treat for the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: What Starts Conversation at a Brooklyn Girl Dinner?
description: Inside an intimate gathering with New York’s creative crust to celebrate a colorful shoe.
content: As the vice-presidential debate buzzed over the airways, a lower-stakes debate unfolded in Brooklyn. Adam Brody: cute, hot or handsome?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Where Literary Ghosts Linger: A Book Critic Goes to Dublin
description: The Irish city, once home to the likes of James Joyce and Oscar Wilde, is known for its bookstores, libraries and pubs, where writers found inspiration over pints of Guinness.
content: This summer, my wife, Cree, and I went to Dublin to celebrate our 30th wedding anniversary. We chose it over more exotic destinations because it made sense to us: I’m a book critic and she’s a writer. How could we not go to Dublin, perhaps the most literature-soaked city in the world? The literary ghosts still stalk the medieval streetscapes — so many ghosts that they collide into one another and seem to make up a spectral and talkative rugby team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Is R.T.O. Finally a Reality?
description: There are some signs of resurging office attendance since Labor Day, and some companies are demanding that workers show up five days a week.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at office attendance, an indicator of how New York City is faring. We’ll also find out what a 45-year-old union contract has to do with school bus delays and driver shortages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: ‘Ring of Fire’ Solar Eclipse Will Be Visible in Parts of South America
description: Not everyone will be able to see the phenomenon, known as an annular eclipse, on Wednesday, though a partial solar eclipse may be visible in parts of Antarctica and Hawaii.
content: Sky watchers in parts of South America are in for a treat on Wednesday, when the moon will pass between the sun and Earth to produce an annular eclipse — an extraordinary moment that will create a “ring of fire” in the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: CBS Sought the Middle Ground on Fact-Checking. Vance Jumped Into the Gap.
description: During Tuesday’s vice-presidential debate, JD Vance clashed with a moderator over whether the ground rules allowed her to clarify his comments about immigrants in his home state.
content: It was a fact-checking flashpoint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine Withdraws From Mining Town That Long Defied Russian Attacks
description: Vuhledar had been under assault for almost three years. Russian forces entered it after a furious battle, and Ukraine ordered troops to retreat.
content: The Ukrainian military said on Wednesday that it was ordering the last of its forces to retreat from the ruins of Vuhledar, a mining town that had served as a vital defensive bastion for nearly three years in eastern Ukraine, after it was stormed by Russian troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The V.P. Debate Came Down to One Moment
description: JD Vance’s response to a question about challenging this year’s election results was telling.
content: The most consequential and revealing exchange during the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday came toward the end, when JD Vance was asked whether he would seek to challenge this year’s election results. That one moment proved that he can’t be trusted with the office he seeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By R.L. Stine
title: R.L. Stine’s Favorite Halloween Books Will Give Your Kids Goosebumps
description: As spooky season approaches, the master of children’s horror recommends creepy-crawly classics and modern thrills for young readers.
content: When you write scary stories for a living, everyone assumes that Halloween must be your favorite holiday. But when I think about Halloween, I often remember it as a day of heartbreaking disappointment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth
title: Officials Cast Doubt on a Dementia Drug, but Human Trials Continue
description: The S.E.C. alleged shortcomings in research said to support the drug, and its developer agreed to a $40 million settlement. Some experts wonder why clinical trials have not been stopped.
content: A drug touted by a small pharmaceutical company as a treatment for Alzheimer’s disease has had a turbulent bid for regulatory approval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Ozzie Virgil Sr., First Dominican-Born Major Leaguer, Dies at 92
description: An outstanding fielder though never an All-Star, he broke that barrier with the Giants in 1956 and later became the Tigers’ first Black player.
content: Ozzie Virgil Sr., who became the first Dominican native in major league baseball when he played third base for the New York Giants in 1956, and who took the field two years later as the Detroit Tigers’ first Black player, died on Sunday at his home in Monte Cristi, a city near the Dominican Republic’s border with Haiti. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: How Russians Serve the State: In Battle, and in Childbirth
description: President Vladimir Putin is throwing ever more resources at two interlocked priorities: recruiting more soldiers and encouraging bigger families.
content: What the Kremlin wants from Russians now boils down to two things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Finding the Right Rep for a Repertory Company
description: Dayton Contemporary Dance Company brought a mixed bill to the Joyce Theater, including a Paul Taylor classic and a dance by the great Rennie Harris.
content: Since it was founded in 1968, Dayton Contemporary Dance Company has often been compared with Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, founded 10 years before. And with Philadanco and Dallas Black Dance Theater, which started up soon after. These troupes share a focus on the African American experience but also, perhaps less obviously, a model. They are repertory companies, which means they are forever facing the question: What repertory will best serve their dancers and audiences?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Christian Monterrosa
title: Stranded in North Carolina’s Mountains, ‘You Can’t Tell That the World’s Going On’
description: With no way for cars to get into Bat Cave, N.C., food and water have been dropped off by helicopters or carried over the river on foot or by a raft.
content: Morgan Ladlee and her fiancé loaded their backpacks with supplies and began a journey up the mountain that, a week ago, would have taken about five minutes by car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: Doug Wheeler’s Celestial Wonder, Now Gallery-Size
description: Paint, plastic and flashbulbs: What the visionary artist achieves with those materials is astounding in its effect.
content: The materials checklist for “Day Night Day” (2024), the artist Doug Wheeler’s perception-bending, full-body freak-out at David Zwirner in Chelsea, barely gives anything away: reinforced fiberglass, flat white titanium dioxide latex, gloss white epoxy, LED light — plastic, paint and lightbulbs, essentially. A shopping list easily fulfilled at most local hardware stores. Yet what Wheeler achieves with those materials is astounding in its totalizing effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaleigh Rogers
title: The V.P. Debate Might Boost Vance and Walz, but It Probably Won’t Shift the Polls
description: Voters may view JD Vance and Tim Walz more positively after Tuesday’s debate. But it’s unlikely to have much impact on their choices for president.
content: When Senator JD Vance of Ohio and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota took the debate stage Tuesday night, a significant share of Americans had not yet formed opinions about either vice-presidential candidate, according to recent polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Vance and Walz’s Battle of the Network Co-Stars
description: In what could be the last prime-time showdown of the 2024 campaign, the supporting players performed against type.
content: If a presidential election is a TV series — and partly it is, like it or not — then the vice-presidential debate is usually a departure episode: an installment that briefly shifts focus to a couple of side characters. It might be memorable or forgettable, but it is generally skippable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: Ex-Frat Leaders Sentenced in Hazing Death of Penn State Student
description: Brendan Young, 28, and Daniel Casey, 27, will spend two to four months in prison for their roles in the 2017 death of Timothy Piazza, a 19-year-old from New Jersey.
content: Two men charged in the 2017 hazing death of a Penn State sophomore that prompted new legislation imposing tougher charges in similar cases were sentenced to two to four months in prison on Tuesday, prosecutors announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily LaBarge
title: When Artists Found Beauty in London’s Toxic Fog
description: Monet and Turner found something sublime in the polluted 19th-century city — and maybe something darker, too.
content: If you’ve been to London recently (or ever) you’ll probably recognize Claude Monet’s description: “Today the weather was maddening, gusts of snow, then sunshine, fog and dark weather and clear, it was magnificent but all too changeable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Rivers
title: Want People to Embrace Public Health? Make It More Like Weather Forecasting.
description: Public health experts too often fail to sound the alarm.
content: In 1925, a tornado cut a track hundreds of miles long, flattening schools and houses across three Midwestern states. At points, the storm was nearly a mile wide and appeared to observers not as a thin funnel but as a wall of angry clouds. Nearly 700 people lost their lives, making it the deadliest tornado in U.S. history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: A Shift Among Democrats: Embrace Record Levels of Oil and Gas
description: Tim Walz said climate change is real, but boasted about high U.S. levels of oil and gas production. JD Vance called climate change “weird science.”
content: JD Vance and Tim Walz on Tuesday both avoided talking about the main cause of global warming that is powering the kind of violent weather that struck the Southeast this week: the burning of fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Gilead Agrees to Allow Generic Version of Groundbreaking H.I.V. Shot in Poor Countries
description: Many middle-income countries are left out of the deal, widening a gulf in access to critical medicines.
content: The drugmaker Gilead Sciences on Wednesday announced a plan to allow six generic pharmaceutical companies in Asia and North Africa to make and sell at a lower price its groundbreaking drug lenacapavir, a twice-yearly injection that provides near-total protection from infection with H.I.V.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Apple’s A.I. Is Landing Soon on iPhones. Here’s What It’s Like.
description: The initial version of Apple Intelligence focuses on helping you with words and photos. Prepare to be impressed and unnerved.
content: Apple’s most important new product of the year (sorry, it’s not a $3,500 headset) will arrive this month. Apple Intelligence, a suite of software tools bringing what Apple describes as artificial intelligence to its devices, will be released through free software updates for owners of some iPhones, Macs and iPads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Kamalei Kakimoto
title: Read Your Way Around Hawaii
description: To read Hawaii is to understand that much of it will never be accessible to the masses. The writer Megan Kamalei Kakimoto recommends books that illuminate the islands’ rich history and storytelling spirit.
content: It shouldn’t have to be said that Hawaii is not your paradise, but I’m saying it anyway. Please understand: This is not an attempt to erect a hostile barrier, but an entreaty to take the responsibility seriously. To read Hawaii is to understand that much of Hawaii will never, should never, be accessible to the masses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Should I Press My Adult Son to Break Up With His Girlfriend?
description: A reader worries that her 29-year-old son is stringing along his girlfriend of nearly three years: She wants marriage and children, but he’s not sure she’s “the one.”
content: My 29-year-old son has been dating his girlfriend for nearly three years. She must be wondering when they’ll move in together and get engaged. My son is not sure that “she’s the one,” but he hasn’t told her that. His reluctance to take their relationship to the next level is an indication, of course, but apparently, his girlfriend does not see this as a red flag. I assume that’s because she thinks things will change. I am very concerned for her: She’s 30 and wants marriage and children. I have told my son that he should end the relationship if he cares about her. Still, it continues. My husband says that I should stay out of this, but I’m wondering if I should push harder for my son to end things. Your thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen and Kendra Sanchez
title: Video Footage Shows Fatal Shooting of Kentucky Judge
description: A preliminary hearing in the case against a former sheriff yielded details about his interactions with the slain judge before he was killed.
content: Video of the fatal shooting of a judge in Kentucky was played in court on Tuesday, as prosecutors presented evidence of their case against the ex-sheriff charged with carrying out the killing on Sept. 19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: ‘Nothing Left to Lose’: Why Are Britain’s Conservatives So Upbeat?
description: At its annual convention in Birmingham, the party is energized by a leadership contest and seems largely undisturbed by broader questions over its electability.
content: Britain’s Conservative Party suffered the worst election defeat of its modern history less than three months ago. Yet one would be hard pressed to find much evidence of it at the party’s annual conference in Birmingham, where the drinks flowed, conversation crackled and the mood could be only described as light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: ‘If Germany Can Do It, Why Can’t We?’
description: Germany’s unilateral decision to close its borders has angered its neighbors in Europe.
content: In 2015 when Angela Merkel, the former center-right chancellor of Germany, declined to shut her country’s doors to asylum seekers coming into Europe, she garnered bouquets from liberals, but also hoots from the far right and grumbling from European neighbors miffed that Germany was unilaterally taking the high ground without taking their interests into account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Mogg
title: How to Stop Straining Your Eyes
description: That achy, tired feeling comes from more than just screen time. Experts share tips for easing the discomfort.
content: After staring at your laptop for hours or scrolling through social media on your phone, you may sense a heavy achiness or bleary-eyed feeling creep in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel J. Wakin
title: Pete Rose Never Changed, but Baseball Did
description: It has begun to acknowledge what Rose knew: That sports are deeply intertwined with gambling.
content: During the 1970s, the era of peak Pete Rose, Major League Baseball still maintained an air of innocence. Nary a betting booth was to be found in a stadium, game broadcasts had not a single FanDuel ad, and the leagues lacked an Official Sports Betting Partner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: The Whiplash of a Major Fashion World Shake-up
description: Celine shocked the industry by announcing that Hedi Slimane, its top designer, is leaving. Hours later, it surprised many again by naming his replacement.
content: In one of the swiftest rounds of fashion musical chairs in recent memory, Celine announced on Wednesday that Hedi Slimane would be leaving his position as the label’s artistic director, but his post wasn’t vacant for long. Hours later, the brand named Mr. Slimane’s replacement: Michael Rider, a former design director at Celine who most recently oversaw Polo Ralph Lauren’s women’s wear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Walz Says He ‘Misspoke’ About Being in Hong Kong During Tiananmen Square Protests
description: At the vice-presidential debate, Gov. Tim Walz tried to dismiss a previous misstatement as insignificant and said he could be “a knucklehead at times.”
content: Asked by a debate moderator on Tuesday why Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota had said that he was in Hong Kong during the Tiananmen Square massacre in June of 1989, when he had in reality been in his home state of Nebraska, Mr. Walz said he was “a knucklehead at times.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Man Who Set Fire to Cabin in the Grand Canyon Gets 20 Months in Prison
description: The 21-year-old was arrested in May, shortly after he set fire to his former girlfriend’s residence in the park, the authorities said.
content: An Arizona man who set fire to a cabin where his ex-girlfriend was living in Grand Canyon National Park was sentenced last week to 20 months in prison and forced to pay over $20,000 in restitution, according to court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: A Venture Capital Firm Does Something Rare: Give Money Back
description: CRV, based in Silicon Valley, plans to return to investors $275 million because the market for mature start-ups has soured.
content: Venture capital firms raise money — lots of it — and invest it in start-ups in hopes of generating big returns. One thing they rarely do is give the money back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Robert Chiarito, Alan Blinder and Jeremy W. Peters
title: The Campaigns Need Younger People to Vote. Did the V.P. Debate Help?
description: At three colleges, there were snacks, big screens and homework assignments. But energy and enthusiasm were sparse — and by the end, even more so.
content: In the pivotal battleground of Wisconsin, where presidential elections are won or lost by only tens of thousands of votes, students like those at the University of Wisconsin-Parkside are highly sought after.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein on the V.P. Debate
description: The Oct. 2, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Claire Gordon about the vice-presidential debate between JD Vance and Tim Walz. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Hurricane Helene
description: What is your reaction to this image? What does it tell you about the impact of the storm?
content: Hurricane Helene, a powerful Category 4 storm when it made landfall, carved out a devastating path through the Southeast, leading to destruction and record-level flooding that stretched more than 600 miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: After a Decade, Scientists Unveil Fly Brain in Stunning Detail
description: Scientists have mapped out how 140,000 neurons are wired in the brain of the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster.
content: A fruit fly’s brain is smaller than a poppy seed, but it packs tremendous complexity into that tiny space. Over 140,000 neurons are joined together by more than 490 feet of wiring, as long as four blue whales placed end to end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: JD Vance and Tim Walz Debate Draws 43 Million Viewers
description: The figure is significantly lower than the vice-presidential debate in 2020.
content: The vice-presidential debate between JD Vance and Tim Walz drew 43.1 million viewers on Tuesday night, significantly fewer than the face-off between the vice-presidential candidates in 2020, according to Nielsen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Yan Zhuang
title: Three Men Arrested After Explosions Near Israeli Embassy in Denmark
description: The arrests were made after two explosions, possibly from hand grenades, were reported near the embassy early on Wednesday morning, the police said.
content: The police in Copenhagen arrested three men in connection with two explosions that occurred near the Israeli Embassy just north of Copenhagen early Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, J. David Goodman, Edgar Sandoval and Christopher Flavelle
title: After Flooding, FEMA Aid Is Arriving. But Some Are Still on Their Own.
description: Six days after Hurricane Helene, North Carolina was getting help from the Federal Emergency Management Agency and others. But officials still faced obstacles reaching some areas.
content: In the western mountains of North Carolina outside of Asheville, the small communities of Cruso and Canton, wrecked by Hurricane Helene, were not waiting for help from the state or the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: The Jewish New Year Is Far More Bitter Than Sweet in Israel
description: On Rosh Hashana, many Israelis longed for a return to normalcy after a year of escalating wars for the country.
content: Jews around the world traditionally usher in Rosh Hashana by dipping apples in honey in the hope of sweet times ahead. But Israelis’ celebrations were muted on Wednesday evening amid the nation’s escalating conflicts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: New Evidence Was Unsealed in the Federal Election Case Against Trump
description: Also, Biden ordered 1,000 troops to help areas destroyed by Helene. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: A federal judge in Washington made public portions of a sprawling legal brief in which prosecutors provided the fullest picture yet of what they found in their investigation of Donald Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: On Child Care, Vance Tests a Talking Point Democrats Also Embrace
description: Both vice-presidential candidates say the government should spend more on child care, a rare point of agreement. But there are still major differences in how they talk about families and gender roles.
content: In a Tuesday vice-presidential debate studded with surprising points of agreement between two starkly different candidates, an extended discussion of child care stood out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: JD Vance’s Old Yale Law Classmates Raise Money for Springfield’s Haitian Residents
description: Some donors said they were seeking to repair damage the Trump-Vance campaign, and Mr. Vance himself, had caused by spreading bogus rumors that migrants were harming pets.
content: Dozens of former classmates of Senator JD Vance of Ohio spent Tuesday night’s vice-presidential debate donating money to a fund for Haitian immigrants in Springfield, Ohio, raising more than $10,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Missing Out on Coldplay’s India Tickets, Some Fans Vented — Even to Police
description: When 13 million people tried to buy tickets for the band’s Mumbai shows, the ticketing site crashed. Many who came up short cried foul, both online and to the authorities.
content: When tickets for two Coldplay concerts in Mumbai, India, went on sale last month, about 13 million people visited an online ticketing platform to vie for around 90,000 seats. Within minutes, the show was sold out and the platform had crashed, only for the tickets to later be offered on other sites at steeply marked-up prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Vance’s Dominant Debate Performance Shows Why He’s Trump’s Running Mate
description: He’s making a case for Trump’s record far more effectively than Trump has ever been capable of doing.
content: The first half of the vice-presidential debate has been the strongest illustration in this campaign so far of why it made sense for Donald Trump to pick JD Vance as his running mate. The Ohio senator is delivering one of the best debating performances by a Republican nominee for president or vice president in recent memory and making a case for Trump’s record far more effectively than Trump has ever been capable of doing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan DiTrolio
title: Curious About How The Times Is Covering the Election? Send Us Your Questions.
description: The election is fast approaching. New York Times editors and reporters want to answer your questions about how we will cover one of the biggest nights in news.
content: The 2024 election is just weeks away, and nearly everyone at The New York Times is contributing to coverage in at least some small way. Reporters are on the campaign trail with the candidates, sharing insights along the way; data editors are breaking down the results from the latest polls; software engineers are ensuring The Times’s website is ready to handle a surge of traffic on election night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Misogyny of Gen Z Men Has Been Overstated
description: The majority of them support equality, even if they don’t call themselves feminists.
content: A major story line of this election season has been the gender gap among Gen Z voters, with young women expressing much more liberal views than young men. Sometimes it can sound like young men are all misogynist incels, addicted to video games and manosphere influencers like Andrew Tate. Young men, it seems, are bitter about their declining fortunes, and they’re taking it out on women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and Jacey Fortin
title: Biden Surveys Wreckage From Helene and Deploys 1,000 Troops to Assist
description: Officials are still uncovering the extent of the devastation in western North Carolina, which President Biden took in from the air. The storm killed at least 183 people in six states.
content: President Biden on Wednesday took an aerial tour of the devastation from Hurricane Helene and ordered the Pentagon to deploy up to 1,000 active-duty troops to assist with aid efforts as rescue workers continued dangerous rescue missions in remote mountain communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë Lescaze and Tony Floyd
title: New Mexico Is Where the Outlaw Artists Live
description: Over the past century, the state has provided refuge for renegades like Agnes Martin and Judy Chicago. It still does, even with a new wave of arrivals closing in.
content: BELEN, N.M., IS a sun-bleached stucco town set in a vast expanse of desert. From here to the horizon, there’s almost nothing taller than a telephone pole. Highway signs offer ominous haikus (“Notice / Do not pickup hitchhikers / Prison facilities”) and inadvertent riddles (“Dust storms may exist”). Although it’s only 35 miles south of Albuquerque, Belen feels utterly removed from the rhythms of urban life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annemarie Conte
title: What Can Body Language Reveal on ‘Love Is Blind’?
description: As Season 7 begins, an expert says figuring out a participant’s motivation is both an art and a science.
content: Grab a golden goblet. The Netflix series “Love Is Blind” is back, with the first episode of its seventh season having been released on Wednesday, with the host Nick Lachey learning what a situationship is. The series that inspired drinking games (take a sip every time someone says the phrase “genuine connection”) — and is both a reality show and a social experiment — set up shop in Washington, D.C., this time to help 29 singles find love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: We Absolutely Need to Escalate in Iran
description: Iran now presents an intolerable threat to Israel, America and the liberal-international order.
content: Long before he met with his overdue demise last week, Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, offered a theological explanation for why Israel had come into existence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: Want a Better Scone? Try Adding Potatoes.
description: The humble spud has rarely been as sweet as in these sensible-yet-decadent delights.
content: In the world of anthropomorphic vegetables, potatoes loom large. For Americans, there is Mr. Potato Head of the blushing ears and startled eyebrows, the first toy ever featured in a TV commercial, in 1952. Early versions included face parts, felt hair and accessories (hats, glasses, pipe) but no potato; you had to provide your own. Investors initially feared that the toy would be seen as being in bad taste, not because turning potatoes into people is an eerie pastime but because the memory of wartime food shortages was still vivid. It seemed wrong to encourage wasting something that could make a meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Beyoncé Released a Song and Levi’s Saw Its Moment
description: The denim brand was looking for ways to sell more apparel to women, and the megastar gave them a natural spokeswoman thanks to a song on “Cowboy Carter.”
content: Kenny Mitchell, the chief marketing officer at Levi Strauss & Co., knew his team needed to move fast after Beyoncé released the track list for her album “Cowboy Carter” in March. Out of the 27 songs listed, one provided the denim brand’s marketing department with a huge opportunity: “Levii’s Jeans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin, Michael Levenson and Graham Dickie
title: Police See No Trace of a Serial Killer in Brooklyn. But 3 Deaths Chill Nightlife.
description: As rumors spin on social media, revelers in one of New York City’s most popular neighborhoods for nightlife are on higher alert.
content: Revelers streamed into the Brooklyn Mirage on a recent weekend to the steady pulse of electronic music. Diplo, the Grammy-winning D.J. playing that night, was not the only thing on their minds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Agnes Chang
title: Here’s Where U.S. Forces Are Deployed in the Middle East

description: A new play from James Ijames, who won a Pulitzer for his “Fat Ham,” has intriguing ideas about identity and community that never fully take shape.
content: In the immortal words of Joni Mitchell, “They paved paradise and put up a parking lot.” In James Ijames’s “Good Bones,” which opened on Tuesday at the Public Theater in Manhattan, it’s not a parking lot that’s the issue but a sports complex. This project is being nudged along by Aisha (Susan Kelechi Watson), a former local who is promoting the arena and building a luxe new home in her old hood as a way to revitalize it.

content: Sally Rooney’s highly-anticipated fourth novel, “Intermezzo,” is about the relationship between a pair of brothers in the wake of their father’s death — and about the women they come to love.

title: Were We the ‘Fat Couple’?
description: When Courtenay was alone with her boyfriend, her body shame disappeared. But when they left the house, it felt different.
content: Courtenay Hameister worked hard to stop feeling shame about her body size, but she also had a cruel inner monologue that just wouldn’t leave her alone. At times, her internalized fatphobia was so powerful, she couldn’t think about romance at all. But when Courtenay started dating Jason, everything felt different. He was fat, too, as well as smart, funny, and handsome.

author: By David Firestone
title: Walz Failed to Expose Vance’s Debate Masquerade

content: JD Vance has always had the ability to switch on and off the outrageousness, to sound reasonable, to paper over a bitter and hollow core with a velvet patter learned at Yale and in countless television appearances. That was the version of himself that he presented to a national audience at the debate on Tuesday night, and it was a world away from how he sounds when campaigning in front of MAGA crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

Tim Walz and Senator JD Vance as urgent to consider because Tehran has “drastically reduced the time it would take to develop a nuclear weapon,” cutting its acquisition time to “one or two weeks.”
